title: My Weird Winter Skin and the Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm That Fixed It
body:
So my skin just gave up. Like, sometime in December. I was sitting there, it was a Tuesday I think, and I looked at my hands and they were just… done. All cracked and red and angry. Like they were mad at me for existing in a house with the heat on. I tried everything. The big tub of O’Keeffe’s Working Hands. That fancy Avene Cicalfate stuff my sister swore by. Even slathered them in straight-up Vaseline before bed and woke up with greasy sheets and still-dry hands. It was a whole thing. Anyway, I was scrolling on my phone, half-watching some baking show, and I kept seeing this word. Tallow. Beef tallow balm. For your skin. I was like, beef fat? On my face? That sounds like something my great-grandma would have used. But my skin was so over it with the normal stuff. I was desperate. So I clicked on this one from some little shop, the Whipped Tallow Balm in Bourbon Vanilla. Smelled like vanilla maybe? Or not. Something. Warm. I don't know. I figured, worst case, I'm out thirty bucks and I have a weird jar of beef fat. My skin couldn't possibly get worse.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Even Became a Thing I Tried

Look, I was skeptical. Very. The whole concept felt… medieval. But then I read the little description while I waited for my laundry to finish drying. It’s whipped beef tallow from grass-fed cows. From France, apparently. They whip it so it’s not just a lump of grease. And the science-ish part, which I only half-understood, is that it’s supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum, or whatever. So it sinks in deep instead of just sitting on top like a plastic bag. That part made a weird kind of sense. All those lotions I’d been using felt like they’d just evaporate or wipe off. Nothing was actually getting in there to fix the dry skin problem. It was just a temporary mask. This tallow skincare idea was saying it could actually work with my skin, not against it. I was still grossed out. But also curious. My knuckles were literally bleeding. I hit ‘buy now’. The package came like a week later. It was small. I remember holding it thinking, this is it? For this whole natural skincare revolution?

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Balm Actually Does

The jar was cute, I’ll give it that. Little and glass. I opened it. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s solid but soft, like cold butter straight from the fridge. You scoop a tiny bit with your finger and it melts immediately from your body heat. That part was cool. You rub it between your palms and it just… disappears into your skin. No greasy film. No shiny residue. It’s wild. My hands just drank it. The smell is not like a candle or a cheap air freshener. It’s not super sweet. It’s just… cozy. Like the kitchen when someone’s baking with real vanilla beans, but after everything’s cooled down. A warm, comforting smell. Not perfume-y. I put it on my cracked knuckles first. Then my elbows, which were like sandpaper. Then, because I was brave, a tiny bit on my cheeks where the winter wind had done a number on me. It felt… fine. Not sticky. Not heavy. Just gone. I didn’t expect much. I went to bed.

Okay so the next morning. This is the part. I washed my hands, like normal. And usually after washing, my skin would feel tight and thirsty immediately. Like it was begging for more lotion. This time? Nothing. My hands just felt like… hands. Normal. Not tight. Not dry. Just fine. I looked at my knuckles. The red cracks were still there but they looked less angry. Less open. Like they were finally starting to close up shop. I was shocked. I kept using it. Morning and night. Just a tiny dab. After like, four days, the cracks were basically gone. My elbows were smooth. Not “baby soft” or whatever, just… not rough anymore. I could wear a wool sweater without it catching. It was fixing the winter damage without any drama. It just worked. I started putting a little on my face at night too, after my serum. My fine lines around my eyes looked… plumper? I don’t know. Less crepe-y. Like my skin was actually hydrated from the inside out. I told my mom about it. She thought I was insane until I gave her my jar to try on her gardening hands. She texted me two days later asking for the link.

## A Quick Tangent About Hotel Soap

This is random but it made me think of it. The whole experience reminded me of this super expensive hotel I stayed at once for a work thing. They had this amazing soap in the bathroom. It lathered like a dream and made your skin feel incredible, not stripped. I loved it so much I tried to find it to buy. Turns out it was like, eighty dollars for a bar. Eighty dollars! For soap! I remember feeling so defeated. This tallow balm thing gave me the opposite feeling. It’s this simple, almost forgotten ingredient that works better than a lot of the fancy, over-engineered stuff in shiny packages. It feels like a secret. A weird, beefy secret. Sorry, got sidetracked. Where was I?

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar now. The first one lasted me almost two months using it on my hands, elbows, and face nearly every day. You need so little. I got mine from this little Etsy shop, just a person making it in small batches. It feels good to buy from that instead of some huge corporation. The bourbon vanilla scent is my favorite, it’s just a warm, classic smell that doesn’t clash with anything. It’s become my winter skin anchor. When the heater’s blasting and the air is dry, I know I can just use this and my skin won’t freak out. It’s not a miracle cure for everything. But for dry, angry, cracked skin? It’s the best thing I’ve found. By a mile. My bathroom shelf has less junk on it now. I just have this, a cleanser, and sunscreen. It simplified everything.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I get, it’s really similar to the oils our skin already makes, so it absorbs deep and helps repair your skin barrier. It doesn’t just sit on top. My face loves it, especially at night.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this too. But no, not for me. Because it melts and absorbs so completely, it doesn’t feel like it’s clogging anything. It’s not like putting coconut oil on your face. It just sinks in. If you’re super acne-prone, maybe patch test first, but it’s been fine for my combo skin.

**What does the Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s hard to describe. It’s not a sugary vanilla cupcake smell. It’s warmer. Deeper. Like vanilla extract and maybe a little bit of… warmth? It’s cozy. It smells expensive, but in a natural way. Fades pretty quick after you put it on, too.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult this winter, or just always feels dry no matter what you put on it, this might be worth a shot. I was super skeptical about the whole tallow thing, but now I’m just a person with normal-feeling hands again. And I’m pretty happy about that. I’m probably gonna order another one soon so I don’t run out.
